reviewText: Successful talk show host Carol Cartman has won fame and wealth by being selfish, cold and ruthless, but she is about to see what she has given up...As she takes a nap in her dressing room before filming her Christmas eve show she is visited by the ghost of her aunt Marla (Dinah Manoff), who's own bad attitude and fame-hungry ways rubbed off onto Carol. Dear old Marla is now doomed to walk the earth for eternity to atone for her ill treatment of others.Marla hopes to save Carol from a similar fate, so has help from the ghosts of Christmas Past (Gary Coleman), Present (William Shatner) and Future (not credited) to show Carol how she changed from a lovely young woman into the caricature she is today. She also learns how her behaviour affects those closest to her, such as her personal assistant Roberta (Nina Siemaszko, sister Beth (Paula Trickey) and lost love John (Jason Brooks). After these sobering and eye-opening experiences Carol receives a glimpse into what her future holds for her if she fails to change her ways...Yes - this is a modern re-telling of A Christmas Carol, so there is a lack of surprising twists in the film, but - call me old fashioned if you want - what is wrong with reminding us to be nice to others and that our actions affect the people around us? It remains one of the most retold messages as it is still [and always will be] extremely relevant.I'm sure many people will be put off by reading that the stars for this are Tori Spelling, Gary Coleman and William Shatner, I've not had any luck in getting my family to watch my DVD for this reason. But I can say that I think the cast is very able; Tori in particular has excellent timing and delivery for making her lines appear humerus, such as the following exchange [I saw this clip on TV in New York a few years ago and it stuck in my head and made me look for the DVD]:Carol: I'm a little busy, so...Christmas Past: Too busy to save your soul from eternal damnation?Carol; OK, yeah, maybe I can give you a couple of minutesIt doesn't sound funny wrote down, but when you see Tori deliver it you'll chuckle, trust me. I usually find William Shatner very irritating but he is very endearing here as Christmas Present and he is very believable whenever he suddenly goes from jolly to somber. My favourite ghost however, is Christmas Past - how can you not love him after the following line from Gary Coleman?Carol: What happened to you?Christmas Past: I grew up. Well, I grew older. There's not much work for a middle aged actor who's even too small to be a jockey.Other standout performances are: Aunt Marla - Dinah plays it loud and brassy, with tongue firmly in cheek, whilst on the living side Carol's harried PA and single mother Roberta is incredibly easy to sympathise with. I'll also mention the character of the talk show producer Jimmy (Michael Landes) as he also puts in a memorable performance.I'm not sure why this has been certified as only being suitable for ages twelve and above; There is no swearing, no violence and the ghosts aren't portrayed in a way that I can see as frightening to young children. I think this is a perfect festive film, the sets are bright and the soundtrack is jolly - I think the production of A CAROL CHRISTMAS rivals most major films, which are similarly themed, I was really surprised to learn that this was made for TV.
summary: A great festive film for all of the family...

reviewText: First of all, the star does not look as bad in the movie as she does in the photo that is on the cover.This is an effective rendering of the story.  Much better than "An American Christmas Carol."  The leading role could have been better cast but she did not harm the movie, and some of the other cast were actually appealing (such as the woman who played her assistant and the child who played her sister's niece).  The only drawbacks were the heavy-duty rock music during the opening credits and during the falling-in-love sequence.  It jars with the spirit of the rest of the movie.  Fortunately, you can fast-forward over both without missing any of the story.(Another annoyance unrelated to the movie is the commercial promo for another movie at the beginning of the DVD.  You can't skip to the menu, you can only fast-forward over it.  To make matters worse, the promo is for a horrible Christmas movie called A Christmas Child.)Still, this movie is worth seeing more than once.  The fact that her life is contemporary makes it closer to our own than the original Scrooge story, and this makes the movie hit harder.

reviewText: I've lost count of the number of versions of Charles Dickens' Christmas Carol I've seen, but I love them all. Of course, I have my favorites. Strangely enough, I rank Tori Spelling's version as the Scrooge-like character high on the list. The script is not that fabulous, but, there's just enough camp to make me forgive every flaw.I never pass up a chance to watch this DVD at Christmas, but, this particular version is great any time of year when I need a little lift -- and a reminder that it's always good to be good to others!
summary: ANY TIME I need a little Christmas!

reviewText: A Christmas Carol is one of those universally themed stories that are easily adaptable to any modernday situation.  The unforgettable admotion to love each other and to help those less fortunate is a truth not just for Christmas but, (perhaps even more so), throughout the year.  "A Carol Christmas" is a wonderful modern adaptation that keeps the true spirit of the original story but adds humor.Carol Cartman, (wonderfully portrayed by Tori Spelling), is the star of her own talk show.  Ruthless to employers and strangers alike, she is the terror of all who come in contact with her.  While preparing for her Christmas Eve show, Carol is visited by her long-deceased Aunt Marla, who tells her to expect visitations from three spirits.  As Carol embarks upon a journey through her past, present, and future, she makes startling discoveries that will never be forgotten.I was especially surprised by the treatment of "Marley's Ghost" in this version.  We see Carol's Aunt Marla in an almost  sociopathic personality.  Unlike the pitiable ghost of Dickens' tale, Marla is brash and extremely unlikable.  I was uncomfortable with this portrayal at first, but then I thought that this interpretation made more sense and actually worked.  Dinah Manoff turns in a wonderful performance.The supporting cast is really wonderful, particularly William Shatner as the Ghost of Christmas Present.  The Ghost of Christmas Past is marvelous as well.Please give this excellent movie a chance.  God bless you all.  Merry Christmas.
summary: Moving and True to the Spirit of the Dickens Classic

reviewText: I admit to being a glutton for the story of "A Christmas Carol", by Charles Dickens and both Hollywood and England have used this wonderful story in countless film realizations. While 2003's "A Carol Christmas", would never be up on the pedestal with the likes of the versions starring Alistair Sim and Geoerge C. Scott I found it a delightful modern turn on the story with some surprisingly effective performances and moments. Tori Spelling may at first glance seem an unlikely choice for the scrooge like lead character who thanks to visits by three spirits on Christmas Eve learns the error of her ways, however she did a good job in the role. Her change of heart towards her fellow man at the conclusion which always seems to be the hardest part of the Scrooge character for actors to make believable was also handled properly by Ms. Spelling. The real joy of this movie for me however was the welcome return of Gary Coleman as the Ghost of Christmas Past in a rather wistful performance that was in many ways quite autobiographical. He brings some much valued humour and indeed a little sadness into the story making his part of the story the most interesting.Almost everyone is familiar with the age old story of "A Christmas Carol", and how the old miser Scrooge is visited by three spirits over the course of one Christmas Eve who proceed to teach him the error of his ways. In this modern version Tori Spelling plays meaner than mean Carol Cartman the host of a talk show that is mainly geared towards exploiting its guests in th ename of higher ratings than it is in trying to make the world a better place. Carol is tight fisted and domineering and strikes terror into the hearts of all her production crew, in particular her much put upon personal assistant Roberta (Nina Siemaszko) and her production manager Jimmy (Michael Landes). Carol has so little regard for her production team that she begrudges even buying them Christmas gifts, a job she delegates to Roberta to do in her own time even though she herself is busy with her young child. Taking a nap just prior to the start of her Christmas Eve telecast Carol is visited by the disturbing spirit of her aunt Marla (Dinah Manoff), who in life was the mean and hard as nails main driving influence in Carol's life and made her sacrifice much in her climb to the top as a talk show host. Marla warns Carol that she will end up like she has become if she does not reform her ways and informs Carol that she will be visited by three spirits who will take her on a journey that she will never forget. The visits of the three spirits take Carol back over her life as she sees her literal adaption by Aunt Marla who takes over her life and drives her reluctantly on to success hardening the young girl along the way. Carol gets to see how Marla destroyed her chance at happiness with good spirited boyfriend John (Jason Brooks), and how she has got to where she now is treating her staff not as responsible human beings but as her slaves. The visit of the Ghost of Christmas future in particular brings Carol into reality when it is revealed just what everyone actually thinks of her after her death and how few people really care what happens to her. Awakened from her sleep Carol is jolted into action to avoid this terrible fate that could be hers if she doesn't change her ways and during her Christmas Eve telecast she turns over a new leaf in her relations with her co workers,her viewing audience, former boyfriend John, and her long estranged family who she then spends Christmas Eve with at a happy conclusion."A Carol Christmas", benefits most from both a beautiful look and the featured veteran television stars who appear as the spirits. William Shatner in the dual roles of television personality Dr. Bob, and the Ghost of Christmas has alot of fun with his role in a comic performance and he teams especially well with Tori Spelling however I enjoyed the rare reappearance by Gary Coleman the most. His character while also driven with comic lines has serious undertones and an often sad demeanour to him playing a "washed up child performer from television", who is now the Ghost of Christmas Past. Long after his great stardom on the television series "Different Strokes", Gary Coleman laces his dialogue with many wry comments about the effects of stardom and what to do when the limelight has gone which made me hope that this talented performer is given more to do in the future as an adult. Dinah Manoff in the old Jacob Marley role redone here as carol's aunt is also effective as the real villian of the piece and she is positively hateful in the flash back sequences where she is depicted manipulating the young Carol into becoming what she was not capable of achieving herself. I really enjoyed the romantic element between Nina Siemaszko as Carol's harrassed assistant Roberta in the revamped Bob Crachit role, and handsome Michael Landes as the producer of Carol's chat show. Their scenes together really had a warm feeling about them in particular with Roberta's daughter in the Christmas decorating scene. Overall the look of "A Carol Christmas", had the trademark glossy appearance associated with Hallmark productions and that fine Christmasy look and feel makes it a worthy although not classic addition to any Christmas movie collection.Many would say "why yet another version of "A Christmas Carol"?", and certainly I asked it myself just that before viewing this DVD however I feel there is room for one more modern variation on this immortal story. The colourful visiting ghosts and Gary Coleman in particular give "A Carol Christmas", its own distinct look and feel and the timeless message of the Charles Dickens story is still as relevant and worthy of thought no matter what form the story assumes. Hallmark have a unique way of creating pleasing Christmas movies and this well produced and glossy looking Christmas story is well worth revisiting each Christmas. Enjoy!
summary: Modern Turn On The Classic Charles Dickens Christmas Story

reviewText: It seems as if Hollywood will never tire of remaking the Dickens classic "A Christmas Carol" in as many different variations as humanly possible.  A Carol Christmas is yet another remake, this one a made-for-TV film that first appeared on the Hallmark Network a couple of years ago.Tori Spelling stars (incredibly) in a production NOT by her famous father.  She is Carol Cartman (no relation to Eric) who is a nasty, mean talk show host who treats everyone poorly and whose only thoughts are on her continued success in the limelight.  Spelling actually does a better job than you'd think she would but she's unfortunately hurt by a rather wooden script that has little heart.Admittedly things pick up in a campy sort of way when she's visited by the ghost of Christmas Past played by Gary Coleman, and the Ghost of Christmas present played by Bill Shatner.  Let's see...Tori, Spelling, Gary Coleman, Bill Shatner all together?  It sounds like a Howard Stern show.  I guess you love or hate Shatner and I love him.  He and Adam West are two of the greatest hams in the history of television and they always bring a smile to my face.All in all, it's not that bad.
summary: A SMALL BIT OF  HOLIDAY CHEER

reviewText: "A Carol Christmas" (not "A Christmas Carol") stars Tori Spelling as the titular character Carol Cartman, a successful, career-driven TV show host who despises everything Christmas represents. Hallmark's modernized Christmas Carol is just as light and fluffy as can be and it is not exactly the greatest adaptation of the Dickens' story, but overall this is a pleasing rendition of a very famous story.On Christmas Eve, Carol is visited by three ghosts - first Ghost of Christmas Past (Gary Coleman) and Ghost of Christmas Present (William Shatner), the latter in Santa Claus costume. The plot of the Dickens classic remains the same although the story's key elements are significantly changed. Bob Cratchit is Carol's long-suffering assistant Roberta (Nina Siemaszko). Marley is Aunt Marla (Dinah Manoff), an overbearing stage mom-like figure to Carol.Tori Spelling is surprisingly convincing as the Scrooge-like heroine, who gradually realizes mistake she has made. Perhaps the best part of the program is William Shatner, who is fun as the merry "ghost" (with one funny reference to "Star Trek"). Dinah Manoff's manipulating aunt is also worth watching. Tom Amundsen's script is serviceable with several interesting changes to the story ("Tiny Tim" is a girl, for instance) though some of them seem unnecessary.This is a feel-good film for everyone. The ending is too sweet (everybody gets everything he/she needs, after all) and is not outstanding, but "A Carol Christmas" is not a bad choice for Christmas.
summary: Hallmark's Modernized Christmas Carol Is Not That Bad
